It must be recognized that such a service would
be competing in many cities with 20, 30 or even 50
other stations.. It must therefore offer something
more than worthwhile programming. If the audience
is to find it at all, this service must have a clearly
definable character, or sound. Just as listeners can
pick out certain rock and roll stations the minute they
tune to them, so must listeners be able to identify
this sort of programming in a flash.
We believe this can be done -- that a service can
be produced that will be distinctive as to quality and
content, and also as to the 'â€™sound" it makes. This
programming would have to be offered daily in large
blocks of time over stations that reach influential
populations in large cities. Other stations would,
also, presumably, want to broadcast the entire offering
of this service. Many would for various reasons pick
up only part of it.
But we propose that a group of five to eight
stations form the nucleus of the network, help determine
its policies, provide basic production facilities for
program origination, and commit the necessary amounts
of their own air time to a single format. These stations
would become the key affiliates of the system and would
create the system's public identification.
Other optional affiliates would take from the
system whatever programs they wanted, either live or
by tape delay, and thus extend the coverage of the best
programs. Presumably, stations from this optional
category would be added to the nucleus from time to time.
It is important to note that this system is not
seen as the only possible national public radio system.
